abstract.text: A three-dimensional shape (also called a model or mesh) that can be displayed in a scene, with attached materials that define its appearance.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: In SceneKit, geometries attached to
objects form the visible elements of a scene, and
objects attached to a geometry determine its appearance.

You control a geometry’s appearance in a scene with nodes and materials. A geometry object provides only the form of a visible object rendered by SceneKit. You specify color and texture for a geometry’s surface, control how it responds to light, and add special effects by attaching materials (for details, see the methods in Managing a Geometry’s Materials). You position and orient a geometry in a scene by attaching it to an
object. Multiple nodes can reference the same geometry object, allowing it to appear at different positions in a scene.

You can easily copy geometries and change their materials. A geometry object manages the association between immutable vertex data and a mutable assignment of materials. To make a geometry appear more than once in the same scene with a different set of materials, use its inherited

method. The copy shares the underlying vertex data of the original, but can be assigned materials independently. You can thus make many copies of a geometry without incurring a significant cost to rendering performance.
You can animate a geometry object. The vertex data associated with a geometry is immutable, but SceneKit provides several ways to animate geometry. You can use a
or
object to deform a geometry’s surface, or run animations created in an external 3D authoring tool and loaded from a scene file. You can also use methods in the
protocol to add custom GLSL shader programs that alter SceneKit’s rendering of a geometry.
SceneKit provides several ways to introduce geometry objects to your app:
Action
For further information
Load from a scene file created using external 3D authoring tools
Use and customize SceneKit’s built-in primitive shapes
, and
Create 3D geometry from 2D text or Bézier curves
Create a custom geometry from vertex data
, Managing Geometry Data

abstract.text: Returns the object returned by .
Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
The common interface for attaching animations to nodes, geometries, materials, and other SceneKit objects.
Methods common to the
and
classes for measuring location and size.
A six-sided polyhedron geometry whose faces are all rectangles, optionally with rounded edges and corners.
A right circular cylinder geometry whose ends are capped with hemispheres.
A right circular cone or frustum geometry.
A right circular cylinder geometry.
A plane that can optionally display a reflection of the scene above it.
A three-dimensional shape (also called a model or mesh) that can be displayed in a scene, with attached materials that define its appearance.
The geometry element identifying which edges of the geometry’s surface should remain sharp after subdivision.
The geometry source specifying the smoothness or sharpness of edges after surface subdivision.
Returns the geometry element at a specified index.
The number of geometry elements in the geometry.
An array of geometry elements that describe the geometry’s shape.
The first material attached to the geometry.
Creates a new geometry object with no content (or default content).
Creates a geometry from the specified Model I/O mesh object.
Creates a new geometry built from the specified geometry sources and elements.
Attaches a material to the geometry at the specified index.
An array of
objects for managing the geometry’s appearance when viewed from far away.
Returns the first material attached to the geometry with the specified name.
An array of
objects that determine the geometry’s appearance when rendered.
A name associated with the geometry object.
Removes a material attached to the geometry.
Replaces a material attached to the geometry with another.
An array of geometry sources that provide vertex data for the geometry.
Returns the geometry sources for a specified semantic.
The number of subdivisions SceneKit uses to smooth the geometry’s surface at render time.
A container for index data describing how vertices connect to define a three-dimensional object, or geometry.
A container for vertex data forming part of the definition for a three-dimensional object, or geometry.
An alternate resolution for a geometry that SceneKit automatically substitutes to improve rendering performance.
A set of shading attributes that define the appearance of a geometry’s surface when rendered.
An object that manages smooth transitions between a node’s base geometry and one or more target geometries.
A structural element of a scene graph, representing a position and transform in a 3D coordinate space, to which you can attach geometry, lights, cameras, or other displayable content.
A rectangular, one-sided plane geometry of specified width and height.
A right rectangular pyramid geometry.
A container for the node hierarchy and global properties that together form a displayable 3D scene.
An object that manages the data-reading tasks associated with loading scene contents from a file or data.
Methods for customizing SceneKit’s rendering of geometry and materials using Metal or OpenGL shader programs.
A geometry based on a two-dimensional path, optionally extruded to create a three-dimensional object.
An object that manages the relationship between skeletal animations and the nodes and geometries they animate.
A sphere (or ball or globe) geometry.
A geometry based on a string of text, optionally extruded to create a three-dimensional object.
A torus, or ring-shaped geometry.
A tube or pipe geometry—a right circular cylinder with a circular hole along its central axis.
Basic shapes—such as spheres, boxes, and planes—and features for generating 3D objects from 2D text and Bézier curves.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
